metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Isthmian Steamship Lines

facts.text: The respondent, Messrs. Isthmian Steamship Lines, is a company incorporated in the United States of America and owns steamships which visit India.
The company's Indian profits, computed on the basis of day on round voyage, are assessed to tax under the Indian Income-tax Act as a company through its agents, Messrs. Angus Co., Ltd.

In the course of the assessment for the years 1941-42, 1942-43 and 1943-44, the company claimed that its unabsorbed depreciation at the end of 1938-39 should be deemed to be a part of the depreciation allowance for 1939-40 and therefore such unabsorbed depreciation should be allowed to be further carried forward under Section 10(2)(vi) of the Income-tax Act.
This claim was negatived by the Income-tax Officer, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax and the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

The Tribunal, at the instance of the company, referred the following question to the High Court: 'Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of this case the Tribunal was right in holding that the unabsorbed depreciation at the end of the year 1938-39, which was not given effect to in the subsequent years, could be treated as part of the allowable depreciation for the relevant assessment years which are assessment years 1941-42, 1942-43 and 1943-44.'
The High Court answered the question in favour of the company, and gave a certificate to the Commissioner of Income-tax under Section 66A(2) of the Act to appeal to this Court.
In the assessment for 1940-41, the Income-tax Officer decided that unabsorbed depreciation from end of 1938-39 could not be carried forward, and the company did not appeal against that order.
The assessment year 1938-39 corresponds to the assessee's accounting year for the calendar year 1937.

In assessment year 1938-39, the assessee showed unabsorbed depreciation which under unamended section was permitted to be carried forward into accounting year 1938 for assessment year 1939-40, but Income-tax Officer refused to allow it.
The assessment year 1939-40 ended on 31st March 1940.

legal_issues.text: Whether the unabsorbed depreciation at the end of the year 1938-39, which was not given effect to in the subsequent years, could be treated as part of the allowable depreciation for the relevant assessment years 1941-42, 1942-43 and 1943-44.
Whether the company can be allowed to carry forward the unabsorbed depreciation remaining at the end of 1938-39 and treat it as part of the depreciation for 1939-40 and thereafter.
Whether the dates '1st April, 1939' and '1st April, 1940' apply to accounting year or assessment year.
Whether assessment year 1939-40 is a year which ended prior to 1st April, 1939.

petitioner_arguments.text: The matter could not be reopened in subsequent assessments because in 1940-41 assessment, ITO decided against carry forward and no appeal was filed by assessee.
By reason of the amendment of Section 10(2)(vi), the respondent-company was not entitled to carry forward the unabsorbed depreciation at the end of 1938-39.
Full effect could not be given to unabsorbed depreciation not for reasons in the section (no profits) but due to failure to appeal against 1940-41 assessment.

respondent_arguments.text: Unabsorbed depreciation at end of 1938-39 should be deemed part of depreciation allowance for 1939-40 and carried forward to 1941-42 etc. under Section 10(2)(vi).

court_reasoning.text: The material changes in amended Section 10(2)(vi): depreciation based on written down value except for ocean-going steamers; unabsorbed depreciation from year ended prior to 1 April 1939 not carried forward.
Dates apply to assessment year, not accounting year, as law applied is that in force in assessment year.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Old law applied up to and including 1939-40 assessment year.

court_reasoning.text: Unabsorbed depreciation from 1938-39 carried forward to 1939-40 under old law; for purpose of reference, treat as unabsorbed in 1939-40 due to insufficient profits.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mandatory provision of old section makes it part of allowance for 1939-40.

court_reasoning.text: Assessment year 1939-40 ended 31 March 1940, not prior to 1 April 1939, so not excluded; unabsorbed depreciation for 1939-40 can be carried forward to 1940-41 and succeeding years if not absorbed due to no profits or insufficient profits.
Section uses 'where full effect cannot be given' not 'has not been given'; profits were less than allowance, so requirements satisfied regardless of no appeal.
First ground of AAC (no appeal in 1940-41) not in reference; authorities accepted Tribunal's rejection of it.

holdings.text: The High Court rightly answered the question in favour of the assessee; company entitled to carry forward unabsorbed depreciation from end of 1938-39 via 1939-40 to subsequent years.
Unabsorbed depreciation for a year becomes by legal fiction part of allowance for succeeding year.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference to High Court and appeal to Supreme Court; carry forward of unabsorbed depreciation before and after 1939 amendment

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court upheld the High Court's answer in favour of the assessee, holding that the unabsorbed depreciation at the end of 1938-39 could be carried forward through 1939-40 to the relevant assessment years 1941-42, 1942-43 and 1943-44 under Section 10(2)(vi).
outcome.relief_granted: Assessee entitled to carry forward unabsorbed depreciation as claimed.

key_quotes.text: "where full effect cannot be given to any such allowance in any year, not being a year which ended prior to the 1st day of April, 1939, owing to there being no profits or gains chargeable for that year".
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key proviso in amended Section 10(2)(vi) allowing carry forward except for pre-1 April 1939 years.

key_quotes.text: The words used in the section are - where full effect cannot be given, and not where full effect has not been given.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes reason for non-allowance; focuses on insufficient profits, not procedural failure.

key_quotes.text: In income-tax matters the law to be applied is the law in force in the assessment year unless otherwise stated or implied.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Determines application of dates to assessment years.
